div1.fw:
Mari Sandoz
Ellsworth, Nebr. 422 Hudson St.
New York, 14 N.Y
div1.p: You are, as always, most generous hearted. Thank you.

You must know that I wouldn't doubt your statement about anything including your sitting up alone with Tibbles and his dead wife, Bright Eyes. I didn't mean only that the absence of her sisters and brother was unIndian but that it was unpioneer as well.

I know that the LaFlesches were aristocracy of east Nebraska, whatever the color. Those who were daughters of Mary LaFlesche, the daughter of Dr. John Gale, post surgeon at Fort Atkinson, were particularly cultured individuals, I suspect. These included both Dr. Susan and Bright Eyes, as you will remember.
Have you ever written this story up for publication? -- not just included in Dr. Aly's biography, but as you tell it. You should, you know.
We still hear fine words about your talk to the Westerners. It always startles the New Yorkers to discover that there are still honest and sincere artists left in the world.

closer.salute:
May 1961 be a magnificent year for
you and in the good Sioux way,
for everybody.
